title: Why are CDs still used for audio instead of DVDs? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because there was a war. The DVD specification includes audio DVDs and they are a thing. Unfortunately at the time the audio DVD was launched, Sony as they always do launched their own proprietary format (SA-CD) instead, and having a big market share for DVD players and controlling a lot of the content they chose not to support playing audio DVDs on their players to boost the proprietary SA-CD format. As is usually the case when a war breaks out - no one wins. There was no cost aspect to this - DVD players cost no more to manufacture than CD players, and DVD discs cost no more to manufacture than CDs. It is possible to have a DVD on one side of the disc and a CD on the other side, it is called a Duodisc and I have one of these. They did not catch on because Sony had destroyed the market for audio DVDs There might have been an outcry that we are stuck with the poor audio quality of CDs with their mere 16-bit audio, but in practice subjective testing demonstrates that no one can hear any better than the 16-bit resolution a CD provides. Time has moved on and physical media is not quite as popular as it once was, and compressed audio download offers a wide range of audio qualities and formats that do everything that you could do with DVD audio. This has left CDs as the defacto standard for the dwindling minority who still like to have their physical media because an audio CD can be played in any CD or DVD player - even a Sony one! If you are keen you can still master your own audio DVDs and play them on a suitable player from downloaded content…

Why are CDs still used for audio instead of DVDs? Why people do things is a mystery… In general, I would suggest that the number of existing CD players, especially in vehicles, but also in room-based facilities is driving people to keep purchasing them. In addition, there is very little supply of being able to get audio on DVDs. A DVDs has much more capacity than can easily be filled. On a single 700 MB CD, I can put 90–120 mp3 songs. This is a nightmare if you want to charge $1–1.25 per song. No one is going to pay $100+ for a single disc of material. Now consider a 8.6GB (8,800 MB) DVD, that would be, roughly, 1,200 songs. Yeah.

Two different formats attempted to use a DVD disc as the physical medium for a replacement for the venerable Audio CD format - both substituting much higher resolution audio, supporting multiple channels, and adding sophisticated copy protection. They even technically still exist - DVD-Audio and Super Audio CD. Unfortunately (or fortunately, dependent on one's viewpoint) neither really caught on with the public, relegating both to niche status. In short, the quality gains weren't significant without massive hardware investments (if at all), they required new (and far more expensive) player hardware, and the CD ripping craze would have been made all but impossible if either format had taken over. And since then, the iPod, music downloads and streaming services have made such a format even more irrelevant to 95%+ of consumers.

As others mentioned, DVD audio was a format with great audio quality that never caught on. They even tried it again with Blu-ray, and there are Blu-ray audio discs with amazing sound. For whatever reason, these just didn’t sell well enough. I do find it odd that I can get my movies in lossless 7.1 studio master surround, but for music, I’m usually stuck with 2-channel stereo and CD quality that’s been around since the late 70’s. Even if it is better than CD quality, it often isn’t by much - people don’t want music that’s streamed or stored on their hard drive taking up a ton of space. A DVD can use up to 9GB, and a Blu-ray up to 50GB, for many channels and very high quality. I do wish I could get my music in the same quality I hear it during scenes in movies.

CDs? In my house, we use one of these:  (NAS - Network Attached Storage - basically a tiny computer with two hard disks that servers their contents over the network) A lot of modern audio equipment comes with an Ethernet port on the back, and with support for DLNA:  (just run Plex or Serviio or something on your NAS, connect them both to the same network, and done)  Anyway, by the time the DVD format appeared, we had all switched to MP3. There are indeed audio formats based on DVD, but… playing music from round silvery pieces of plastic went out of fashion hard, and never came back.

Music on physical media will be over soon, except for enthusiasts wanting real records, i.e. vinyl. Nobody is interested in replacing a CD player with a DVD player when we have all the music we need on Spotify, on our phones etc. CD is the last advancement of physical media for music, much as DVD was for movies. Blu Ray happened, kind of, but it never actually replaced DVD. Nobody wants to carry around something big enough to play a DVD when we have thousands of songs on our phones, or just use Spotify and listen to pretty much anything you like, at any time.

Cost and the amount of data stored. While there were some Audio DVD’s to get all the quality they had out of them you needed high end gear. They died out quickly. Since standard audio takes up so little room the normal recording length does not come anywere close to using up the data limit on a DVD, but it fits well on a CD. And CD’s cost less.

It is because the world follows international standards. For the compact disc music distribution is the Red Book Standard‎: ‎IEC 60908. Nothing stops you from storing data in different formats to save storage and money but it is another thing to manufacture and distribute music worldwide in a format every one agrees and that every intended playback machine is capable of reproducing.

A2A: The normal amount of time required for a typical album does not require nearly as much storage space as is available on a DVD. There still exist a great many audio CD players that cannot play music from any other sort of medium. People still want to be able to continue to use them.

Audio requires far less data than video, so a CD can hold an hour of uncompressed digital audio easily? Video has to be compressed even on DVD or Blu-ray discs. One second of uncompressed audio requires less than 0.2 megabytes. One second of uncompressed 4K video requires nearly 1500 megabytes.

Because in the evolution of audio CDs, the CD carried enough information to hold a whole album. Using a DVD for that, would be a waste of space. The general music quantity is still the album, as a music collection, as the market still dictates.
It is a waste of money to use a DVD for music applications! If you can store 100 music records in a regular CD, Can you imagine how many music records a DVD can store?
There is nothing stopping you from storing audio files in a DVD; however, an audio album fits just fine in a CD and CDs are cheaper, so why waste storage?
Because CDs do the job and they can be played with any player. DVD audio would have been practical mainly on some operas. Now CD is mainly just a distribution format an people who buy the rip them.

Because by the time we were getting ready to start putting music on dvds, the internet and subsequent streaming services started to grow. There was also hesitation over the idea of needing to buy yet another piece of electronics to play your music.
